column1: A Well That Never Dries;Nam Tchun-Mo;false;"Nam Tchun-Mo (*1961) represents a contemporary continuation of the Dansaekhwa movement
column2: a South Korean art movement that was already working in a radically abstract
column4: and increasingly three-dimensional manner in the 1960s. Through repetitive actions in a meditative painting practice
column5: he creates a contemporary interpretation of „golbeop“ (骨法)
column6: a classical principle of East Asian painting that emphasizes the structural vitality and life force of brushwork. He organically traverses tradition and contemporaneity
column9: as well as personal memories and collective cultural experience. The central formal elements of Nam Tchun-Mo‘s practice are lines reminiscent of furrowed fields and elements of traditional architecture such as lattice windows and rafters.

column1: „A Well That Never Dries“ is the second book about and with Nam Tchun-Mo in our program after „Beam Lines Spring Stroke“ (2019) with which we venture away from photography into painting and sculpture
column2: a rare but very welcome excursion for us.

column1: Nam Tchun-Mo lives and works in Daegu
column3: Germany. He exhibits regularly in Korea and Europe

column4: Reactor Block 4 of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant suffered the worst-case scenario in the history of civil nuclear power. Nearly ten years later

column8: and the landscape. What began as a nature study in 2015 evolved through repeated travels to Kyiv over the past year into a highly topical testimony of the political present in Ukraine. At the heart of the 2025 works is the resilience of the people in Kyiv and the Exclusion Zone
column9: set against the backdrop of the ongoing Russian war of aggression. “The project brings the journey full circle
column10: ” says the photographer. “We are returning to the people to whom we already gave a voice in 1995.Today
column11: we are documenting a society standing between destruction and an unconditional determination to pursue a European future.”

column2: Volker Kreidler presents an extraordinary photographic documentation that traces Ukraine’s transformation from the post-Soviet spirit of change to the current war of defense against Russia.

column1: Volker Kreidler (*1962) has been dedicated to the photographic exploration of Eastern Europe since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. His work navigates the tensions of rapprochement with the West and the associated challenges concerning democracy

Tres Viajes;Jörg Brüggemann;false;"Jörg Brüggemann has traveled to Chile and South America three times. On one of his trips
column2: he drove several thousand kilometers across the continent
column3: capturing landscapes and encounters in his photographs. He was inspired to do so by a dream in which he encountered his deceased mother. On another trip
column4: he photographed political unrest and demonstrations in Valparaíso. The three trips—there are three chapters in the book—are
column6: far more journeys of dreams and feelings—perhaps also in search of himself—than documentary images of places
column8: or political circumstances. The three chapters
column9: which are wonderfully distinct from one another in their design and materiality while remaining intertwined
column10: read like narrative strands that cannot be explained immediately
column11: as they leave room for personal discoveries and fantasies. A short personal text by the author continues this narrative style in words. It is also interesting that the photographer
column12: who in his last book pursued a sober topic such as the German autobahn over several years
column13: now shows that a travel narrative can perhaps also be a healing process for oneself and that inner images enable a completely unique
column14: not always explainable approach to the world.

column1: Jörg Brüggemann (*1979) has been a member of the Ostkreuz agency since 2009 and is co-director of the renowned Ostkreuzschule in Berlin.

Buchenwald In the Thicket of the Ettersberg;Christian Rothe;false;"Between 2017 and 2024
column2: the Leipzig-based photographer Christian Rothe (*1986) explored the vast area of the former concentration camp Buchenwald on the Ettersberg near Weimar
column3: using his analog large-format camera. Ruins
column6: fences and paths appear as topographical scars and signs in the impenetrable thicket. What began as a careful and tentative exploration gradually evolved into an intensive search for traces of history obscured by nature. The black and white photographs enter into a dialog with the poem (Der gefesselte Wald) by José Fosty and literary passages from internationally renowned novels by former concentration camp inmates: Bruno Apitz’s “Naked Among Wolves”
column7: Imre Kertész’s “Fatelessness” and Jorge Semprún’s “What a Beautiful Sunday”. Essays by curator Andrea Karle
column8: chairman of the World Council of Churches
column9: Heinrich Bedford-Strohm and editor Günter Jeschonnek on Christian Rothe’s visual language
column10: the significance of contemporary remembrance culture and commemoration complement the examination of the rupture of civilization and the terror of National Socialism in the immediate vicinity of the town of classicism and great German poets and thinkers. The book was released on the occasion of the eightieth anniversary of the liberation of the Buchenwald concentration camp by the remaining prisoners and the US Army and was presented  for the first time at a matinee on Sunday
column12: 2025 at the Museum of Forced Labor under National Socialism

column2: large-format pictures by Ljubodrag Andric (*1965) are all the more difficult to categorize the longer the viewer gazes at them. Even though Andric makes use of a camera at the beginning of his creative process
column3: he operates at the interface between photography and painting. Between 2019 and 2024
column4: Andric traveled through India and was inspired by the atmosphere of historical buildings to create works that can be described as geometric abstractions painted with light. A special feature of his work is the tactile quality reminiscent of fresco painting
column5: which is also reflected in the choice of materials for this book. The publication
column7: combines two books in one. The classic and equally radical layout by Dutch bookdesigner SYB congenially reflects the visual approach of Ljubodrag Andric’s works. An alternating rhythm of full-page illustrations and double-page details picks up on the impressions and sensations that careful viewers of his originals works may have.
